item.title: this week, #CAAPV focuses on some of the myths behind wrongful...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

this week, #CAAPV focuses on some of the myths behind wrongful convictions. first, we begin with the somber reminder that wrongful convictions are rarely overturned and by acknowledging that many innocent people are in cages with all relief exhausted. wrongful convictions are rarely overturned because the system forever protects itself by prohibitively high legal standards that close the doors of relief and protect bad government actors.

prosecutors often say that exoneratio...ns are the system "working," because it shows that we are able to "catch our mistakes." in doing so, they completely ignore their own culpability in causing those wrongful convictions. they ignore how they used their power to cheat to win at all costs.

and most importantly, they ignore the human being who languished in a cage while lawyers frantically worked to bring their actions to light, on the dim hope that the courts might listen.

prosecutors are the architects of mass incarceration. they are violent cops who protect the police and put our most vulnerable in cages to attempt to silence their voices and to hide their own wrongdoings. and then they call that justice.

#CAAPV #HoldCopsAccountable #DAsAreCopsToo #EndDAImmunity

item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

It's National Exoneration Day -- 54% of wrongful convictions resulting in exonerations were caused by the result of official misconduct - POLICE and PROSECUTORS. And, while African Americans only represent 13% of the U.S. population, African Americans represent 47% of known exonerations.

The National Registry of Exonerations

On #WrongfulConvictionDay, we recognize the tremendous cost of wrongful incarceration and the importance of stopping future false convictions. By documenting ex...onerations and researching the causes of and remedies for wrongful conviction, the Registry hopes to make progress toward eliminating these devastating miscarriages of justice. Please support our work at bit.ly/donateWCD2020, and learn more from The Innocence Network at WrongfulConvictionDay.org.

The prosecutors “exchanged numerous images of Asian people, some accompanied by pejorative comments, and some unexplained,” Judge Giles wrote. “They exchanged ‘jokes’ about Asian stereotypes, and mocking caricatures of Asians using imperfect English.”

One of the emails compared Kenneth Choy, who was a key witness against Ms. Choy, to the character Long Duk Dong from the movie “Sixteen Candles,” Judge Giles wrote. Another suggested that Ms. Choy had committed incest with Kenne...th Choy.

In still another email, sent on the eve of a hearing before the state’s highest court, one of the prosecutors wrote, “I will show up tomorrow wearing a cheongsam and will be the one doing origami in the back of the courtroom.”

item.title: And for this week’s #CAAPV #DidYouKnow: The use of ketamine...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

And for this week’s #CAAPV #DidYouKnow:

The use of ketamine by Colorado paramedics and EMTs responding to calls from the police is not unusual, and needs to be stopped.

This powerful anesthetic is administered to persons purportedly exhibiting “excited delirium,” although the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, and the World Health Organization do not recognize “excited delirium” as a disorder, and the diagnosis has been decried as junk science.

item.title: Proud of #CAAPV’s own Jes Jones for speaking out against...
item.content:encoded:
Colorado Attorneys Against Police Violence

Proud of #CAAPV’s own Jes Jones for speaking out against DPD’s efforts to violently silence protesters, and grateful for the work of National Lawyers Guild of Colorado for their work to protect protestors against DPD’s relentless violence.

In the National Lawyers Guild statement, Jones takes on Polis for implying that protesters are criminal terrorists: "To have the Governor of Colorado equate property destruction as terrorism yet refuse to condemn police killings of unarmed... Black men is unacceptable. Property can be replaced, Black Lives cannot," she maintains.

...

“The arrests are violent, resulting in broken bones and other serious injuries. The criminal charges are being inflated to increasingly serious offenses. Protesters are being forced to risk their safety and freedom in order to exercise their right to free speech," said Jessica Jones — a local criminal defense attorney and volunteer organizer for the Colorado NLG. "It is a sad paradox that protesters experience police violence as they protest police violence."

In addition to violent policing tactics in the name of crowd-control, Denver Police recently began invoking a little-used ordinance that was originally passed in anticipation of the 2008 Democratic National Convention protests. The law bans activists from carrying protective equipment, chains, and bike locks.

"This ordinance has allowed police to criminalize activists before a protest has even started," said Jones.
